paragraphs.text: The Paris unity march shows we must protect freedom of expression, not curtail it further.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: I was just one Australian face in a human sea of more than one and half million Parisians yesterday
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I was trying to comprehend what I was a part of when the placard thrust in front of my eyes made it clear
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "La liberte d'expression n'a pas de religion"- freedom of expression has no religion
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This was a rally to defend the essential global human right to free expression
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A right that should not be bound by religious, cultural or political strictures
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We were marching to remember the victims of the Charlie Hebdo newsroom massacre and the Kosher grocery store siege
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We were marching in sympathy with those in mourning who joined us
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We were marching in defiance, determined to rise above the fear and chaos the terrorists inflicted on our city
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: overwhelmingly, we marched to defend our right to freely express our views
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The main march stretched three kilometres between Place de la Republique and Place de la Nation, tracking down Boulevard Voltaire
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: When I cried "Je suis Charlie, nous somme Charlie!", it was in the spirit of the French philosopher Voltaire's revolutionary words:"I do not agree with what you have to say, but I'll defend to the death your right to say it."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The props of the rally - giant pencils supporting the French flag, a flood of demonstrators holding pens aloft and bibs emblazoned with the faces of the massacred Charlie Hebdo staff - told the story
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Paris has been my home for a year
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I am a research fellow with the World Editors Forum and the World Association of Newspapers and News Publishers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which is based in the city
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It's a long way from the University of Wollongong in Australia
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: where I am on staff as a journalism academic
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But the principle of freedom of expression we were marching to defend binds journalists, writers and artists, and by extension all citizens, globally
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It transcends national borders, distance, culture, language, class and religion
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's why, as we marched, we saw Paris residents hanging models of pencils and banners carrying free speech slogans from their balconies
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: And it's why we paused to listen while a little African girl bellowed "Je suis Charlie!" from a third story window at her mother's side
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We were a calm sea of over 1.5 million people pouring through the grand boulevards of central Paris
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Led by the families of those killed and over 40 world leaders who walked with linked arms, it was a significant moment in history, a moment triggered by outrage at the act of terrorists who massacred journalists and cartoonists in the middle of a weekly editorial meeting and ordinary citizens doing their shopping
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was also a moment fuelled by a collective determination to display unity and defiance in the face of terror and fear
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The attack on Charlie Hebdo and the climate of fear and anxiety it created are, sadly, regular occurrences in countries such as Iraq, Syria, Pakistan and Mexico, where journalists are frequent targets
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The western media too often turns a blind eye to the murder of journalists elsewhere
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Paris unity march represents a watershed moment in the struggle to protect journalists and defend freedom of expression globally
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Kalashnikov-wielding terrorists took the fight into the heart of a newsroom in one of western Europe's biggest cities
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that doesn't wake up complacent democracies to the need to vigorously defend the right to report
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: nothing will
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Once the news cycle moves on from Paris and the cries of "Je suis Charlie" fade, we must harness the levels of public support and political will to enact significant and lasting change globally
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We must be on guard against the already audible attempts to justify a further curtailment of media and internet freedoms in the interests of national security in the aftermath of the Paris terror attacks
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The threats posed to investigative journalism by mass surveillance, data retention and the criminalisation of reporting certain information under anti-terrorism legislation are already significant
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Especially in Australia
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It would be an enormous tragedy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the lasting legacy of the Charlie Hebdo massacre was ultimately a further undermining of privacy and freedom of expression rights
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Let us honour the victims and survivors of the Paris terrorist attacks by finding a sustainable balance between the need for anti- terrorism measures against our collective human right to freely express our views
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As the murdered editor-in-chief of Charlie Hebdo, Stephane Charbonnier, told Le Monde in 2011:"I'd rather die standing than live on my knees."
paragraphs.label: testimony
